[[File:Norblin - Marchand d'images.jpg|thumb|Dealer of art in [[Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth]], (Drawn by [[Jan Piotr Norblin]])]] An '''art dealer''' is a person or company that buys and sells [[works of art]]. Art dealers' professional associations serve to set high standards for accreditation or membership and to support art exhibitions and shows.<ref name="ADAA">[http://www.artdealers.org/dnloads/adaa_guide.pdf Collector's Guide to Working with Art Dealers, 45th Anniversary Edition, The Art Dealers Association of America (ADAA), New York] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131008045449/http://www.artdealers.org/dnloads/adaa_guide.pdf |date=October 8, 2013 }}</ref>
==Role== An art dealer typically seeks out various [[artist]]s to represent, and builds relationships with [[art collector|collectors]] and [[museum]]s whose interests are likely to match the work of the represented artists. Some dealers are able to anticipate [[market trends]], while some prominent dealers may be able to influence the taste of the market. Many dealers specialize in a particular style, period, or region. They often travel internationally, frequenting [[Art exhibition|exhibitions]], [[auctions]], and artists' [[studio]]s looking for good buys, little-known treasures, and exciting new works. When dealers buy works of art, they resell them either in their galleries or directly to collectors. Those who deal in [[contemporary art]] usually exhibit artists' works in their galleries, and take a percentage of the price the works sell for.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=B7u8s0SN7KcC&pg=PA81&dq=art+dealer%27s+percentage+of+the+artwork+price&hl=en&sa=X&ei=AAbXUoOSH-iy0QXf44DQDA&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=art%20dealer's%20percentage%20of%20the%20artwork%20price&f=false Alan D. Bryce, ''Art Smart: The Intelligent Guide to Investing in the Canadian Art Market''], Dundurn, 2007. {{ISBN|1550026763}}, 9781550026764</ref>
==Job requirements== [[File:Gillis van Tilborgh - A Picture Gallery.jpg|thumb|300px|''A Picture Gallery'' by [[Gillis van Tilborch]], 1660s]] Art dealers often study the [[history of art]] before entering on their careers. Related careers that often cross-over include [[curator]]s of museums and [[art auction]] firms are industry-related careers.<ref name="ADAA" /> Gallery owners who do not succeed may seek to work for more successful galleries. Others pursue careers as [[art critic]]s, academics, curators of museums or auction houses, or practicing artists.<ref>[http://www.princetonreview.com/careers.aspx?cid=12 Career: Art Dealer, The Princeton Review]</ref>
Dealers have to understand the business side of the art world. They keep up with trends in the market and are knowledgeable about the style of art people want to buy. They figure out how much they should pay for a piece and then estimate the resale price. They are also often passionate and knowledgeable about art. Those who deal with contemporary art promote new artists, creating a market for the artists' works and securing financial success for themselves. The art world is subject to economic booms and bust just like any other market. Art dealers must be economically conscious in order to maintain their livelihoods. The mark ups of art work must be carefully monitored. If prices and profits are too large, then investments may be devalued should an overstock or economic downturn occur.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://money.cnn.com/2008/04/15/smbusiness/singing_in_rain_art.fsb/index.htm?section=magazines_fsb | author=Cowley, Stacy | title=Amid art boom, dealers brace for a bust | publisher=Fortune Small Business | date=2008-04-16 | accessdate=2008-06-03}}</ref>
To determine an artwork's value, dealers inspect the objects or paintings closely, and compare the fine details with similar pieces. Some dealers with many years of experience learn to identify unsigned works by examining stylistic features such as brush strokes, color, form. They recognize the styles of different periods and individual artists. Often art dealers are able to distinguish authentic works from [[forgeries]] (although even dealers are sometimes fooled).<ref name="ADAA" />
==Notable art dealers== [[File:Frans Francken the Younger - A visit to the Art Dealer - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|300px|''A visit to the Art Dealer'' by [[Frans Francken the Younger]], early 1600s]] * [[Guillam Forchondt|Guillam Forchondt the Elder]] (1608–1678)
A 17th century Flemish Baroque painter and art dealer based in Antwerp. He established an important art dealing business with international connections in Europe maintained by his extended family. He originally trained as a painter and cabinet maker but built a reputation through his international art business. His children became art dealers who settled in various cities in Europe such as Venice, Paris, Vienna, Prague, Linz, [[Passau]] and [[Cadiz]] where they supplied an elite clientele with a variety of art objects. When in the 1670s Flanders suffered a severe economic downturn due mostly to an invasion by the French, Guillam Forchondt and his brother Melchior the Younger became art entrepreneurs by hiring lesser painters to create group projects such as large commissioned copies of famous works or large decorative objects. At one point, the ''Brothers Forchondt'' had 60 painters in service for export to France, Austria, Spain and Portugal.<ref name=RKD>[https://rkd.nl/en/explore/artists/28613 Guilliam Forchondt] in the [[RKD]]</ref>
* [[Matthijs Musson]] ([[Antwerp]], 1598–3 November 1678)
A painter and art dealer based in Antwerp, who helped popularize artists of the 17th century [[Antwerp school]] by marketing them throughout Europe.<ref name="maere">J. de Maere, Jennifer A. Martin, and Marie Wabbes. ''Illustrated Dictionary of 17th Century Flemish Painters''. Brussels: Renaissance du livre, 1994; p. 294. {{ISBN|2-8041-1858-4}}</ref> Many of his correspondences have been published and studies of his business relationships with other dealers across Europe have established ideas about the art trade and its economics.<ref name="maere" /><ref>Neil De Marchi, [[Hans J. Van Miegroet]] and Matthew E. Raiff, "Dealer-Dealer Pricing in the Mid Seventeenth-Century Antwerp to Paris Art Trade," in Michael North and David Ormrod, ''Art Markets in Europe, 1400-1800'', Aldershot: Ashgate, 1998; pp. 113–130. {{ISBN|1-84014-630-3}}</ref> * [[Larry Gagosian]] (born 1945) Head of the multimillion-dollar [[Gagosian Gallery]] group.
* [[Arne Glimcher]] (born 1938) Glimcher is the founder of The [[Pace Gallery]] and is widely known as one of the art world's most powerful dealers. The Pace Gallery represents contemporary artists including [[Chuck Close]], [[Tara Donovan]], [[David Hockney]], [[Maya Lin]] and [[Kiki Smith]]. It also represents the estates of several artists, including [[Pablo Picasso]], [[Agnes Martin]], [[Ad Reinhardt]], and [[Alexander Calder]].<ref name="Bloomberg">[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601088&sid=a1O4sidv4.xg&refer=muse Dealer Arne Glimcher Thinks Art Market Is `A Little Bit Crazy' - Bloomberg.com]</ref> During his career he has worked closely with important artists including [[Jean Dubuffet]], [[Robert Rauschenberg]], [[Louise Nevelson]], and [[Lucas Samaras]]. In 2007, Glimcher received the Distinguished Alumni Award from the Massachusetts College of Art and Design.
* [[Edith Halpert]] (1900–1970) Halpert was born in 1900 in [[Odessa]], arrived in the U.S. as a penniless Russian [[Jewish]] immigrant and grew to become a pioneering New York City art dealer, transforming the landscape of [[Modern art]]. Over her forty-year career from 1926 through the 1960s, Halpert brought recognition and market success to many [[avant-garde]] American artists. Her establishment The Downtown Gallery, one of the first in Greenwich Village, introduced and showcased many modern art luminaries. Halpert died at age 70 a multimillionaire, with [[Sotheby's]] crediting her with having put modernist painting auctions on the map. Its posthumous sale of her collection went for million in 1973.
* [[Klaus Perls]] Perls (1912–2008) was born and raised in Berlin. He studied art history in Munich, but was forced to finish his education in Basel, Switzerland, as the Nazis were no longer allowing degrees for Jews. He ran Perls Galleries for over 60 years. His gallery dealt with contemporary American artists, modern works from the School of [[Paris]] and Mexican and South American art. Perls also developed an interest in art from Benin and built a sizable collection. He was not only an art dealer, but also a donor as he contributed many significant works of art to the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]. He died June 2, 2008 in [[Mount Kisco, New York|Mount Kisco, N.Y.]] at age 96.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/05/arts/design/05perls.html?ref=design | author=Grimes, William | title=Klaus Perls, Art Dealer Who Gave Picassos to the Met, Dies at 96 | publisher=New York Times | date=2008-06-05 | accessdate=2008-06-05| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080612003117/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/05/arts/design/05perls.html?ref=design| archivedate= 12 June 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
* [[Martha Hopkins Struever]] Struever was born in 1931 in [[Milan, Indiana]]. She attended the [[Wood Tobe Coburn School|Tobé-Coburn School For Fashion Careers]] in [[New York City, New York|New York City]], after obtaining her Bachelor of Science degree from [[Purdue University]] in [[Lafayette, Indiana]] in 1953. She began collecting and dealing in [[Native Americans in the United States|American Indian]] art in 1971, and is regarded as a leading scholar on historic and contemporary [[Pueblo Indian]] pottery and [[Pueblo]] and [[Navajo people|Navajo]] Indian jewelry. She has authored books on [[Charles Loloma]], the foremost [[Native Americans in the United States|American Indian]] jeweler, and [[Dextra Quotskuyva]], the pre-eminent contemporary [[Hopi]] potter, as well as exhibition catalogues on [[Hopi]] potter [[Iris Nampeyo]] and other [[Hopi]] art, and has guest curated museum shows in several cities.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.atada.org/ATADA_News2-07.html |author=Bauver, Robert |date=Spring 2007 |title=ATADA Lifetime Achievement Awards - Antique Tribal Arts Community Honors Its Own |journal=ATADA News |publisher=Antique Tribal Arts Dealers Association, Inc. |pages= |accessdate=2009-10-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090718134436/http://atada.org/ATADA_News2-07.html |archivedate=2009-07-18 |df= }}</ref>
* [[Jacques Seligmann]] German-born Seligmann (1858–1923) moved to Paris in 1874 where he set up an antiquarian business in 1880. Benefiting from the interest of clients such as [[Edmond de Rothschild]], he moved to the [[Place Vendôme]] in 1900 and in 1904 opened an office in New York. In 1909, he acquired the [[Polish Embassy, Paris#The H.C3.B4tel de Monaco|Hôtel de Monaco]] in Paris where he was able to impress his more important clients such as the Russian [[Stroganovs|Stroganoff family]] and the high-flying British politician [[Sir Philip Sassoon]]. In New York, he developed interest in European art attracting collectors such as [[Benjamin Altman]], [[William Randolph Hearst]] and [[J. P. Morgan]]. On his death, his son [[Germain Seligman]] continued to run [[Jacques Seligmann & Company]].
* [[John Weber (art dealer)|John Weber]] (1932-2008) Weber was born in 1932 in [[Los Angeles]]. He was a radio corpsman in the [[United States Navy|Navy]] during the [[Korean War]] before receiving a bachelor's degree from [[Antioch College]] in [[Yellow Springs, Ohio]] in 1958. As a contemporary art dealer, Weber was ahead of his time as he was one of the early promotors of Conceptual Art, Post-Minimalist sculpture and Italian Arte Povera. He was the director of several galleries throughout his career and helped organize shows that featured big names such as [[Robert Indiana]], [[Richard Long (artist)|Richard Long]] and [[Andy Warhol]]. Weber died May 23, 2008 in [[Hudson, New York|Hudson, N.Y.]] at age 75.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/01/arts/design/01weber.html?ref=design | author=Smith, Roberta | title=John Weber, 75, Contemporary-Art Dealer, Is Dead | publisher=New York Times | date=2008-06-01 | accessdate=2008-06-05| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080612003444/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/01/arts/design/01weber.html?ref=design| archivedate= 12 June 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
===Other notable art dealers=== {{div col|colwidth=30em}}
* [[Colnaghi & Co]], established c. 1760 * [[Paul Durand-Ruel]], 1831–1922 * [[M Knoedler & Co]], 1846–2011 * [[Duveen Brothers]], (Joseph Joel Duveen 1843–1908, and Henry J. Duveen 1855–1918) * [[Georges Petit]], 1856–1920 * [[Theo van Gogh (art dealer)|Theo van Gogh]], 1857–1891 * [[Jacques Seligmann]], 1858–1923 * [[Alfred Stieglitz]], 1864–1946 * [[Charles Carstairs]], 1865-1928 * [[Berthe Weill]], 1865–1951 * [[Ambroise Vollard]], 1866–1939 * [[Joseph Duveen, 1st Baron Duveen]], 1869–1939 * [[Paul Cassirer]], 1871–1926 * [[Wilhelm Uhde]], 1874–1947 * [[Léonce Rosenberg]], 1879–1947 * [[Herwarth Walden]], 1879–1941 * [[René Gimpel]], 1881–1945 * [[Kurt Walter Bachstitz]], 1882–1949 * [[Paul Rosenberg (art dealer)|Paul Rosenberg]], 1881–1959 * [[Joseph Brummer]], 1883–1947 * [[Goupil & Cie]], 1850–1884 * [[Goupil & Cie|Adolphe Goupil]], 1827–1884 then Boussod, Valadon & Cie, 1884–1919 * [[Daniel-Henry Kahnweiler]], 1884–1979 * [[Hugo Perls]], 1886–1977 * [[Carroll Carstairs]], 1888-1948 * [[Léopold Zborowski]], 1889–1932 * [[Paul Guillaume]], 1891–1934 * [[Georges Wildenstein]], 1892–1963 * [[Katia Granoff]], 1895–1989 * [[Sidney Janis]], 1896–1989 * [[Samuel M. Kootz]], 1899–1982 * [[Pierre Matisse]], 1900–1989 * [[Betty Parsons]], 1900–1982 * [[René Drouin]], 1905–1979 * [[Leo Castelli]], 1907–1999 * [[Ileana Sonnabend]], 1914–2007 * [[Heinz Berggruen]] 1914–2007 * [[Daniel Wildenstein]], 1917–2001 * [[Jock Truman]] 1920–2011 * [[André Emmerich]], 1924–2007 * [[Gregg Juarez]], 1925– * [[Ivan Karp]], 1926–2012 * [[Richard Bellamy (art dealer)|Richard Bellamy]] 1927–1998 <ref>[http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/oralhistories/transcripts/bellam63.htm interview with Richard Bellamy, 1963, Archives of American Art, retrieved February 1, 2009]</ref> * [[Jan Krugier]], 1928–2008 * [[David Whitney]], 1939–2005 * [[Robert Miller (art dealer)|Robert Miller]], 1939–2011 * [[Bruno Bischofberger]], 1940– * [[Charles Cowles (art dealer)|Charles Cowles]], 1941– * [[Mary Boone]], 1951– *[[Jack Tilton]] - 1951 - 2017 * [[Serge Sorokko]], 1954– * [[Thaddaeus Ropac]], 1960– * [[Dominique Lévy]] * [[Helly Nahmad (London)]], 1976– * [[Karsten Greve]], 1946– {{div col end}}

(ATADA)[http://www.atada.org/] * Art Dealers Association of America (ADAA)[http://www.artdealers.org/] * Art and Antique Dealers League of America (AADLA)[http://www.artantiquedealersleague.org/] * Association of Art and Antiques Dealers (LAPADA)[http://www.lapada.org/] * British Art Market Federation (BAMF) * British Antique Dealers' Association (BADA)[http://www.bada.org/] * Confédération Internationale des Négociants en Oeuvres d'Art (CINOA)[http://www.cinoa.org/] * Fine Art Dealers Association (FADA)[http://www.fada.com/] *[[New Art Dealers Alliance]] (NADA)[http://www.nada.com/] * Private Art Dealers Association (PADA)[http://www.pada.net/] * [[Society of London Art Dealers]] (SLAD)[http://www.slad.org.uk/] * The European Fine Art Foundation (TEFAF)[http://www.tefaf.com/]

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Bandista | image = Bandista @ Kreuzberg II.jpg | image_size = 240px | landscape = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank --> | alt = | caption = Bandista in 2006 | background = group_or_band | alias = | origin = [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]] | genre = [[Protest song|Protest]], [[ska]], [[dub music|dub]], [[world fusion]] | years_active = {{start date|2006}}–present | label = | associated_acts = | website = {{URL|tayfabandista.org}} | current_members = | past_members = }}
'''Bandista''' (also stylized as '''bANDİSTA''') is a Turkish [[musical collective]], formed in 2006 in [[Istanbul]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nme.com/nme-video/youtube/id/0mOzglXI9XI | title=Bandista band playing for friends video | publisher=[[NME]] | accessdate=2013-06-08}}</ref> The band is known for their diverse musical style, [[DIY ethic]] and [[Left-wing politics|leftist]] political stance.<ref name="hurriyet" /><ref name="aile" />
Bandista takes its name from the abbreviation of "Bando Istanbul". The band releases their albums [[copyleft|independently for free]].<ref name="hurriyet">{{cite web | url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/pazar/17677869_p.asp | title=Pablo Neruda, biz orada | publisher=[[Hürriyet]] | date=May 1, 2011 | accessdate=June 8, 2013 | author=Dağlar, Ali | language=Turkish }}</ref> Their first release, ''De Te Fabula Narratur'', was mastered in Italy and 1000 copies distributed for free at [[Taksim Square]].<ref name="hurriyet"/> The band's 2012 EP and the latest release, ''Sınırsız-Ulussuz-Sürgünsüz'' was dedicated to Festus Okey, a [[Nigeria]]n immigrant who was a victim of [[police brutality in Turkey]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.radikal.com.tr/yasam/bandistadan_festus_okeyin_anisina-1097751 | title=Bandista'dan Festus Okey'in anısına... | publisher=[[Radikal]] | date=August 21, 2012 | accessdate=June 8, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.cnnturk.com/2012/kultur.sanat/muzik/08/20/bandistadan.festus.okey.anisina/673613.0/index.html | title=Bandista'dan Festus Okey anısına... | publisher=[[CNN Türk]] | date=August 20, 2012 | accessdate=June 8, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.hafifmuzik.org/haber/bandista-hatirlatiyor-festus-okeyi-unutma/ | title=Bandista hatırlatıyor: Festus Okey’i unutma! | publisher=Hafif Müzik | date=August 22, 2012 | accessdate=June 8, 2013 | author=Sayan, Berk}}</ref>
The collective members play various musical instruments for their records, including [[accordion]], [[bass guitar]], [[clarinet]], [[saxophone]], [[snare drum]], [[fiddle]], [[bouzouki]], [[keyboard instrument|keyboards]], [[trombone]], and [[melodica]]. The collective also includes non-musician members.<ref name="hurriyet" /> The members do not disclose their identities and prefer to stay anonymous.<ref name="hurriyet" /><ref name="aile">{{cite web | url=http://www.hurriyetaile.com/eglence/roportajlar/bandista-ailesinde-esitsizlige-yer-yok_7727.html | title=Bandista Ailesinde Eşitsizliğe Yer Yok | publisher=[[Hürriyet|Hürriyet Aile]] | date=August 23, 2011 | accessdate=June 8, 2013}}</ref>
The collective has performed at various festivals and demonstrations.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/foca-to-host-alternative-rock-festival-for-summer.aspx?pageID=238&nid=26403 | title=Foça to host Alternative rock festival for summer | publisher=[[Hürriyet Daily News]] | date=July 27, 2012 | accessdate=June 8, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.radikal.com.tr/turkiye/berfo_ananin_ocagi_tutsun_diye-1134194 | title=Berfo Ana'nın ocağı tütsün diye... | publisher=[[Radikal]] | date=April 20, 2013 | accessdate=June 8, 2013}}</ref> The collective is also a supporter of the [[2013 protests in Turkey|Occupy Gezi]] movement.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.birgun.net/actuels_index.php?news_code=1369904228&year=2013&month=05&day=30 | title=Taksim Gezi Parkı Nöbeti'nde binler buluştu | publisher=Birgün | date=May 30, 2013 | accessdate=June 8, 2013}}</ref>
==Discography== ;Studio albums * ''Ki buradayız hâlâ'' (2014) * ''Bandsista | Sokak Meydan Gece'' (2012) * ''Daima!'' (2011) * ''Dikkat Askersiz Bölge'' (2010) * ''Şu anda! Şimdi!'' (2010) * ''Paşanın Başucu Şarkıları'' (2009) * ''De Te Fabula Narratur'' (2009)
;EPs * ''Sınırsız-Ulussuz-Sürgünsüz'' (2012)
==See also== * [[Grup Yorum]] * [[Grup Munzur]] * [[Komik Günler]]

[[File:Beit lessin.jpg|thumb|Beit Lessin Theater]] '''Beit Lessin Theater''' ({{lang-he-n|תיאטרון בית ליסין}}, [[Transliteration|translit]]: ''Teatron Bet Lessin'') is a theater in [[Tel Aviv]], [[Israel]]. ==History== Established in 1978 by [[Yaakov Agmon]] for the [[Histadrut]],<ref>Linda Ben-Zvi. ''Theater in Israel''. University of Michigan Press, 1996. {{ISBN|0-472-10607-4}}. pg.22. See [https://books.google.com/books?id=v_tXKyDG5j4C&printsec=frontcover&cd=1&source=gbs_ViewAPI&hl=en#v=onepage&q=beit%20lessin&f=false ''Theater in Israel'' on Google Books ]</ref>
Over the years the theater has shown over a thousand contemporary American and European plays, as well as original productions. In 1993, [[Zippi Pines]] started managing the theater. It was separated from the Histadrut and started showing mostly original Israeli material reflecting the political and social situation in Israel.
In 2003, the theater moved from Lessin House to the old residence of the Cameri Theater after it was remodeled. This venue having more seats allowed larger and more expensive plays to be produced, such as [[Chicago (musical)|Chicago]] and [[Guys and Dolls (musical)|Guys and Dolls]].
The theater's production "Mikveh" won the Israeli Theater Prize in 2005. ==See also== *[[Theater of Israel]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.lessin.co.il/ENG/main.asp Beit Lessin English Homepage] {{coord|32|4|46|N|34|46|25.31|E|region:IL|display=title}}

revision.comment: Added "Obama administration controversies" category. As most of the book alleged events occurred during Obama administration.
revision.text:
{{Infobox book | italic title = | name = Clinton Cash:
The Untold Story of How and Why Foreign Governments and Businesses Helped Make Bill and Hillary Rich | image = Clinton Cash cover.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | author = [[Peter Schweizer]] | audio_read_by = Walter Dixon | title_orig = | orig_lang_code = | title_working = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = | language = English | series = | release_number = | subject = Political science/American government | genre = | set_in = | published = | publisher = [[Harper (publisher)|Harper]] | publisher2 = Broadside Books | pub_date = May 5, 2015 | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = 256 | awards = | isbn = 978-0-06-236928-4 | oclc = 906020748 | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = Extortion: How Politicians Extract Your Money | followed_by = | native_wikisource = | wikisource = | notes = | exclude_cover = | website = {{URL|http://www.clintoncashbook.com}} }} '''''Clinton Cash: The Untold Story of How and Why Foreign Governments and Businesses Helped Make Bill and Hillary Rich''''' is a 2015 [[The New York Times Best Seller list|''New York Times'' bestselling]] book by [[Peter Schweizer]] in which he investigates donations made to the [[Clinton Foundation]] by foreign entities, paid speeches made by [[Bill Clinton|Bill]] and [[Hillary Clinton]], and the state of the Clintons' finances since leaving the White House in 2001. It was published by [[Broadside Books]], a division of [[HarperCollins]] and was adapted into both a film and a graphic novel. ==Origins== Schweizer wrote the book using researchers from the [[Government Accountability Institute]] (GAI). The Mercer Family Foundation funded the $2.6 million cost of producing the book with a $1.7 million contribution to the Institute in 2015,{{cite web|last=Mider|first=Zachary|url= https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-01-18/-clinton-cash-book-got-most-of-its-funding-from-hedge-fund-star |title=‘Clinton Cash’ Book Got Most of Its Funding From One Hedge Fund Star|newspaper=Bloomberg|date=January 18, 2017|accessdate=August 3, 2018}}{{cite web|last=Hoffman|first=Andy|url= https://www.investopedia.com/news/trump-donor-robert-mercer-funded-book-clinton-cash-dealings/ |title=Trump Donor Robert Mercer Funded Book on Clinton Cash Dealings|newspaper=Investopedia|date=January 19, 2017|accessdate=August 3, 2018}} which was more than GAI's entire budget for the previous year.{{cite web|last=Mayer|first=Jane|url= https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2017/03/27/the-reclusive-hedge-fund-tycoon-behind-the-trump-presidency |title=‘The Reclusive Hedge-Fund Tycoon Behind the Trump Presidency |newspaper=The New Yorker|date=March 27, 2017|accessdate=August 3, 2018}} ==Synopsis== [[File:Hillary Clinton sworn in as SecState 1-21-09 clinton-SIC-1.21.09 600 1.jpg|thumb|220px|left|[[Hillary Clinton]] being sworn in as Secretary of State in 2009. Her husband and former U.S. President, [[Bill Clinton]], holds the Bible.]] ''Clinton Cash'' is an investigation of the foreign benefactors of Bill and Hillary Clinton and the Clinton Foundation.{{cite news|last1=Becker|first1=Jo|last2=McIntire|first2=Mike|title=Cash Flowed to Clinton Foundation Amid Russian Uranium Deal|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/24/us/cash-flowed-to-clinton-foundation-as-russians-pressed-for-control-of-uranium-company.html|accessdate=28 August 2015|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=April 23, 2015}} It investigates alleged connections between Clinton Foundation donors and Hillary Clinton’s work at the State Department.{{cite news|last1=Karni|first1=Annie|title='Clinton Cash' publisher corrects '7 or 8' inaccurate passages|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/05/clinton-cash-publisher-corrects-7-or-8-inaccurate-passages-117946|accessdate=28 August 2015|publisher=Politico|date=May 14, 2015}} The book argues that the Clinton family accepted lavish donations and speaking fees from foreign donors at times when the State Department was considering whether to award large contracts to groups and people affiliated with those donors.{{cite news|last1=Wofford|first1=Taylor|title=Everything You Need to Know About 'Clinton Cash'|url=http://www.newsweek.com/everything-you-need-know-about-clinton-cash-327694|accessdate=28 August 2015|publisher=Newsweek|date=May 1, 2015}} One of those donors include [[Mohammed Hussein Al Amoudi]], an Ethiopian and Saudi Arabian billionaire businessman. The book has eleven chapters. Some chapters focus on particular transactions or deals, such as the creation of UrAsia Energy and [[Uranium One]] in [[Kazakhstan]], and the connection shareholders had and have to the Clintons. Other chapters focus on a broader set of relationships, particularly with regard to Bill Clinton’s paid speeches during the years Hillary Clinton served as Secretary of State, and whether those paying for his speeches had significant business before the State Department. Schweizer dubs the Clintons' blend of government service and private remuneration the “Clinton blur.” {{cite news|last1=Green|first1=Joshua|last2=Epstein|first2=Jennifer|title=Author Alleges Bill Clinton Just Quit Education Company Because of 'Clinton Cash'|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2015-04-25/author-alleges-bill-clinton-just-quit-education-company-because-of-clinton-cash-|accessdate=28 August 2015|publisher=Bloomberg|date=April 25, 2015}} {{Clear}} ==Publication== ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[The Washington Post]]'' and [[Fox News]] were granted exclusive agreements with the book's author to pursue the story lines found in the book.{{cite news|last1=Sullivan|first1=Margaret|title=An ‘Exclusive’ Arrangement on a Clinton Book, and Many Questions|url=http://publiceditor.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/04/23/an-exclusive-arrangement-on-a-clinton-book-and-many-questions/?_r=0|accessdate=28 August 2015|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=April 23, 2015}} The ''Times'' faced considerable criticism for this arrangement from both its readers and from other media outlets. The paper's own public editor, [[Margaret Sullivan (journalist)|Margaret Sullivan]], said the arrangement was "troubling" and lacked transparency. ''[[Salon (website)|Salon]]'' wrote that Schweizer was not a responsible journalist and that the arrangement showed that right-wing forces were luring the mainstream press into giving attention to gossip and innuendo much as they had during various supposed Clinton controversies of the 1990s.{{cite news |title=The right’s new Clinton obsession just went mainstream: How a sketchy Hillary "exposé" hooked the New York Times |work=Salon |date=April 21, 2015 |url=https://www.salon.com/2015/04/21/inside_the_rights_new_clinton_cash_obsession_the_sketchy_new_hillary_expose_that_hooked_the_new_york_times/ }} In addition, [[Media Matters]] criticized these two newspapers for failing to report in a timely fashion on inaccuracies that had been discovered in the book.{{cite web|url=http://mediamatters.org/blog/2015/05/01/after-forming-clinton-cash-exclusives-ny-times/203492|title=After Forming Clinton Cash "Exclusives," NY Times, Washington Post Fail To Report On Book's Errors|date=30 April 2015|publisher=}} === Clinton campaign reaction === The day the book was published, Hillary Clinton's campaign set up a portal called "The Briefing" on its official website. The Briefing is designed to rebut the allegations made in Schweizer's book. Clinton's campaign manager, [[John Podesta]], wrote: "The book has zero evidence to back up its outlandish claims... While we will not be consumed by these kinds of attacks, we will also not let them go unchallenged."Haberman, Maggie. "[https://www.nytimes.com/politics/first-draft/2015/05/04/clinton-team-bolsters-its-defense-ahead-of-negative-books-release/ Clinton Team Bolsters Its Defense Ahead of Negative Book’s Release]", ''[[The New York Times]]'', May 4, 2015. Accessed: May 6, 2015. Various spokespeople for Hillary and Bill Clinton disputed the book's allegations,{{cite news|last1=Stanton|first1=John|title=Spokesman Disputes Book: Bill Clinton Not Paid For Series Of Speeches|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/johnstanton/spokesman-bill-clinton-was-not-paid-for-speeches-book-says-h#.sypZZdWmv2|accessdate=1 April 2016|publisher=buzzfeed.com|date=April 28, 2015}} e.g. concerning the charges that Clinton was paid for speeches by Irish billionaire [[Denis O'Brien]] of [[Digicel]] in exchange for help in securing telecommunications contracts in Haiti in 2010.{{cite news|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/johnstanton/spokesman-bill-clinton-was-not-paid-for-speeches-book-says-h#.nyXB0X8mD|title='Spokesman Disputes Book: Bill Clinton Not Paid For Series Of Speeches|date=April 28, 2015|publisher=buzzfeed.com}} ==Commercial reception== ''Clinton Cash'' debuted at number two on the [[The New York Times Best Seller list|''New York Times'' Best Seller list]]. In its first week it sold 31,000 copies and was also second on the [[Nielsen BookScan]] ranking for adult nonfiction.{{cite web|last=Milliot |first=Jim |url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/publisher-news/article/66640-clinton-cash-selfish-hit-the-list.html |title='Clinton Cash,' 'Selfish' Hit the List |website=Publishersweekly.com |date=2015-05-15 |accessdate=2016-09-11}} The book stayed on the ''New York Times'' Best Seller list for hardcover non-fiction for five weeks.{{cite news|last1=Paul|first1=Pamela|title=Hardcover Nonfiction Books - Best Sellers - June 21, 2015 - The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/best-sellers/2015/06/21/hardcover-nonfiction/?action=click&contentCollection=Books|accessdate=7 October 2016|work=The New York Times Book Review|publisher=The New York Times Company|date=21 June 2015|quote=5 WEEKS ON THE LIST: CLINTON CASH by Peter Schweizer. Harper/HarperCollins. An examination of donations made to the Clinton Foundation by foreign entities.}} A paperback edition of the book released in 2016 made the relevant ''Times'' best seller list as well.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/best-sellers/paperback-nonfiction/?_r%3D0 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-06-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6iGXZr0Zt?url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/best-sellers/paperback-nonfiction/?_r=0 |archivedate=2016-06-14 |df= }} According to [[Fred Barnes (journalist)|Fred Barnes]] of ''[[The Weekly Standard]]'', the book sold approximately 200,000 copies, in hardcover and paperback as of July 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/hillary-and-bill-clintons-story-of-money-grubbing-and-sleaze/article/2003412|title=Hillary and Bill Clinton's Story of Money-Grubbing and Sleaze|date=21 July 2016|publisher=}} ==Critical reaction and actions taken== Writing for ''[[The Washington Post]]'', academic and political activist (and brief 2016 U.S. Democratic presidential primary opponent of Hillary Clinton) [[Lawrence Lessig]] wrote "On any fair reading, the pattern of behavior that Schweizer has charged is corruption."{{cite news|last1=Lessig|first1=Lawrence|title=Democrats embrace the logic of 'Citizens United'|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/the-clintons-citizens-united-and-21st-century-corruption/2015/05/08/7f11a0d6-f57b-11e4-b2f3-af5479e6bbdd_story.html|accessdate=28 August 2015|work=The Washington Post|date=May 8, 2015}} James Freeman reviewed the book for ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', writing that "Almost every page of the fascinating ''Clinton Cash''... will be excruciating reading for partisans on both sides of the aisle".{{cite news|last1=Freeman|first1=James|title=There’s Money to Be Made |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/book-review-clinton-cash-by-peter-schweizer-1430952794|accessdate=28 August 2015|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|date=May 6, 2015}} Ed Pilkington, writing for ''The Guardian'', reported that it was factually correct that "large donations to the foundation from the chairman of Uranium One, Ian Telfer, at around the time of the Russian purchase of the company and while Hillary Clinton was secretary of state, were never disclosed to the public. The multimillion dollar sums were channeled through a subsidiary of the Clinton Foundation, CGSCI, which did not reveal its individual donors." Following publication and in reaction to areas where it said improvements were warranted, the Clinton Foundation said it would put into place some new procedures for better financial reporting and that it would limit some kinds of foreign donations. Pilkington assessed those claims made by the Clinton Foundation as unlikely to put the matter to rest: "But with Bill refusing doggedly to give up his speaker engagements – 'I gotta pay our bills' – and foreign corporations and super-rich individuals still able to donate to the family charity, it looks like this controversy may run and run." Pilkington also described the book as "an unrestrained attack on the former president and first lady." Pilkington notes that some of the claims in the book have been proven factually inaccurate. According to Pilkington, Schweizer does not prove corruption on the part of the Clintons, but "one of his main contentions – that the former president’s rates skyrocketed after his wife became secretary of state – is correct... pointing to several glaring conflicts of interest."{{cite news|last1=Pilkington|first1=Ed |title=Clinton Cash: errors dog Bill and Hillary exposé – but is there any 'there' there?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/may/05/clinton-cash-bill-hillary-scandal-book|accessdate=28 August 2015|work=The Guardian|date=May 5, 2015}} Several weeks after the book's initial publication, HarperCollins and the author made some corrections to the Kindle edition of the book. Schweizer corrected "seven or eight" passages that were revealed to be inaccurate after the book was released. [[FactCheck.org]] found Schweizer's assertion that Clinton, as Secretary of State, could have stopped Russia from buying a company with extensive uranium mining operations in the U.S. to be false, due to Obama's decision on it.{{cite news|last1=Kiely|first1=Eugene |title='No ‘Veto Power’ for Clinton on Uranium Deal |url=http://www.factcheck.org/2015/04/no-veto-power-for-clinton-on-uranium-deal/|publisher=FactCheck.org|date=April 28, 2015 |accessdate=1 April 2016}} [[PolitiFact]] found the assertion that Clinton changed her views on a nuclear deal with India in response to donations to her family's foundation to be false.{{cite news|last1=Carroll|first1=Lauren|title='Clinton Cash' author: Hillary Clinton changed positions on India nuclear deal |url=http://www.politifact.com/punditfact/statements/2015/may/06/peter-schweizer/clinton-cash-author-hillary-changed-positions-indi/|accessdate=1 April 2016|publisher=PunditFact |work=Tampa Bay Times|date=May 6, 2015}} ==Film adaptation== In May 2016, a [[film adaptation]] of the book, funded by co-founder of [[Government Accountability Institute]] and [[Breitbart News]] executive chairman [[Steve Bannon]] (CEO of the [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016]]), was screened at the [[Cannes Film Festival]].Joshua Green, [https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2016-04-28/clinton-cash-has-been-made-into-a-movie 'Clinton Cash' Has Been Made Into a Movie], Bloomberg Politics (April 28, 2016).[https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/clinton-cash-film-hillary-foundation-finances Clinton Cash film aims to cause likely Democratic nominee maximum damage], ''The Guardian'' (May 12, 2016). [[Time magazine|''Time'' magazine]] reported that conservatives were not the intended audience for the film adaptation of the book: "Environmentalists. Anti-nuke activists. Gay-rights advocates. Good-government folks. They’re all going to find themselves increasingly uncomfortable over claims that the likely Democratic nominee, in the film’s words, takes cash from the “darkest, worst corners of the world.”{{cite web|last1=Elliott|first1=Philip|title=Clinton Cash: A Scathing Film Aimed at Persuading Liberals|url=http://time.com/4328254/clinton-cash-movie-hillary-clinton-peter-schweizer-breitbart/|website=TIME.com|publisher=Time Magazine|accessdate=7 October 2016|location=New York|date=12 May 2016}} The film's U.S. premiere was scheduled for July 24, 2016 in Philadelphia (prior to the [[2016 Democratic National Convention]] there) and the film had a [[limited release]] in four other major U.S. cities in early August. ==Graphic novel adaptation== A [[graphic novel]] adaptation of the book, written by [[Chuck Dixon]] and illustrated by Brett R. Smith, was released by [[Regnery Publishing]] on August 8, 2016.{{cite news|last1=Harper|first1=Jennifer|title=Bill and Hillary: The graphic novel|publisher=''[[The Washington Times]]''|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2016/jul/24/bill-hillary-clinton-featured-in-graphic-novel/|accessdate=5 August 2016|date=24 July 2016}}{{ISBN|978-1-62157-545-0}} In late summer 2016 this graphic adaptation placed itself atop the ''Times'' best seller list for the Hardcover Graphic format.[https://www.nytimes.com/books/best-sellers/hardcover-graphic-books/?_r=0] {{dead link|date=September 2016}} ==See also== * [[Clinton Foundation–State Department controversy]] * [[Dark Money]] * [[Uranium One controversy]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:2015 non-fiction books]] [[Category:American graphic novels]] [[Category:American political books]] [[Category:Books about Bill Clinton]] [[Category:Books about foreign relations of the United States]] [[Category:Books about Hillary Clinton]] [[Category:Books about politics of the United States]] [[Category:Books adapted into films]] [[Category:Books critical of modern liberalism in the United States]] [[Category:Charity scandals]] [[Category:Clinton Foundation|State Department controversy]] [[Category:English-language books]] [[Category:FBI operations]] [[Category:HarperCollins books]] [[Category:Hillary Clinton controversies]] [[Category:Obama administration controversies]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox album| | name = Karl Rove: Courage and Consequence | type = compilation | artist = Karl Rove | cover = Courageandconsequence.jpg | alt = | released = March 3, 2010 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Indie rock]], [[rock music|rock]], [[noise rock]] | length = | label = Seismic Wave Entertainment | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }}
'''''Karl Rove: Courage and Consequence''''' <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.karlrovebook.net |title=Karl Rove: Courage and Consequence (The unabridged audio) |publisher=Karlrovebook.net |date= |accessdate=2010-03-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100308064106/http://www.karlrovebook.net/ |archivedate=2010-03-08 |df= }}</ref> is a grassroots funded <ref name="kickstarter1">{{cite web|url=http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/conanneutron/project-courage-and-consequence-an-lp-comp-cu |title=Project: Courage and Consequence - an LP comp./ culture jam of bands against Rove — Kickstarter |publisher=[[Kickstarter]] |date= |accessdate=2010-03-04}}</ref> compilation of rock songs released on March 3, 2010 <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cdbaby.com/cd/krove |title=Various Artists | Karl Rove: Courage and Consequence |publisher=CD Baby |date= |accessdate=2010-03-04}}</ref> in anticipation of [[Karl Rove]]'s similarly titled [[memoir]]. The subtitle of the record is ''The Unabridged Audio''. It was conceived as "an anticipatory sonic recollection of the gross misdeeds attributable to Rove over the past decade".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://karlrove.bandcamp.com/ |title=Karl Rove: Courage and Consequence |publisher=Karlrove.bandcamp.com |date=2010-02-24 |accessdate=2010-03-04}}</ref>
It is both a [[compilation album]] and [[Music download|digital download]] package, as well as a direct lampoon of ''Courage and Consequence: My Life As a Conservative in the Fight'' written by [[Karl Rove]]. Project: Courage and Consequence <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9l019UQiWdA |title=Project: Courage and Consequence - bumming out Karl Rove |publisher=YouTube |date=2008-12-18 |accessdate=2010-03-04}}</ref> was conceived of, in tandem with the compilation LP to [[Google Bomb]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://seismicwave.net/project-courage-and-consequence/ |title=Project: Courage and Consequence – Seismic Wave Entertainment |publisher=Seismicwave.net |date= |accessdate=2010-03-04}}</ref> the memoir of the similar title and "mess with the search results" <ref name="kickstarter1"/>
==Track listing== # The Heavenly States - "A Man For Our Times" # Rival Dickens - "Forget The Naughts" # Have Special Power - "A Rove By Any Other Name" # Assistant Cobra - "The Art Of Distraction" # Lambs of Abortion - "New American Century" # We're Gonna Fight The Eskimos Next (Members of [[Mount Vicious]], [[Vitamin Party]] and Bwuh) - "Don't Praise The Machine" # Cartographer - "The Biggest Asshole In The World" # Death Dream - "Karl Rove, Let's Get Dirty" # Generalissimo - "Swarm" # Cold Lake - "Courage and Consequence" # Hurry Up Shotgun - "Car Bomb" # The United Sons Of Toil - "Invention Vs Innovation" # Victory And Associates - "Lies, and the Lying Liars that Sell Them"
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * [http://www.eastbayexpress.com/ebx/bands-of-courage-and-consequence/Content?oid=1576998 An interview with curator Conan Neutron in the East Bay Express] * [http://seismicwave.net Seismic Wave Entertainment website] * [http://thirdcoastdigest.com/2010/03/cultural-zero-culture-jamming-karl-rove/ Article about the compilation on Thirdcoast Digest] * [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/conan-neutron/we-just-gave-karl-roves-b_b_490348.html "We Just Gave Karl Rove's Book a New Soundtrack" Article on Huffingtonpost]
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100408045538/http://www.karlrovebook.net/ Project Courage and Consequence Official Site] * [https://twitter.com/bookkarlrove Project Courage and Consequence Twitter] * [http://courageandconsequence.blogspot.com/ Courage and Consequence Blog] * [http://www.last.fm/music/Death+Dream/Karl+Rove:+Courage+and+Consequence Courage and Consequence Last.Fm page] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-NmDRpaCkpQ Mike Malloy Interview 01-23-2010] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZBLjwLJwJ4k Mike Malloy Interview 03-05-2010 pt1] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6PY8qVPagYk Mike Malloy Interview 03-05-2010 pt 2]

page.title: Cultural Center of the Philippines Complex

revision.text:
{{Infobox venue | name = Cultural Center of the Philippines | nickname = ''CCP Complex'' | native_name = '''''Sentrong Pangkultura ng Pilipinas''''' | native_name_lang = | fullname = | former names = | logo_image = File:CulturalCenterPH.svg | logo_caption = | image = File:CCP_Main_Theaterx.jpg | caption = Facade of [[Tanghalang Pambansa]] | pushpin_map = Manila#Philippines | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_caption = | pushpin_label_position = | address = [[Roxas Boulevard]] | location = [[Pasay City]] | coordinates = {{coord|14|33|29|N|120|59|8|E|region:PH}} | type = [[Performing arts center]] | broke_ground = | built = | opened = September 1966 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Government of the Philippines]] | operator = Arsenio Lizaso, President | cost = | architect = [[Leandro V. Locsin]] | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = | tenants = [[Ballet Philippines]]
[[Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company]]
[[National Music Competitions for Young Artists Foundation]]
[[Philippine Ballet Theatre]]
[[Philippine Madrigal Singers]]
[[Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra]]
[[Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group]]
[[Tanghalang Pilipino]]
UST Symphony Orchestra | embedded = | website = {{URL|https://www.culturalcenter.gov.ph/}} | publictransit = }} [[File:Pic geo photos - ph=mm=pasay=roxas blvd.=ccp complex=ccp main theater - aerial shot from legzspi towers 300 -philippines--2015-0625--ls-.JPG|thumb|300px|An aerial view of the [[Tanghalang Pambansa]] and the northern section of the CCP Complex]] [[File:MetroManilajf0040 02.JPG|thumb|300px|The [[Manila Film Center]] in the CCP Complex]] [[File:Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP Main Theater) - distant view (CCP Complex, Roxas Boulevard, Pasay; 2014-10-24).jpg|thumb| The CCP Complex from the [[Roxas Boulevard]].]] The '''Cultural Center of the Philippines Complex''', also known as '''CCP Complex''', is an {{convert|88|ha|adj=on}} owned by The [[Cultural Center of the Philippines]] (CCP) located along [[Roxas Boulevard]] in [[Metro Manila]], Philippines, most of which fall under the jurisdiction of the city of [[Pasay]]. Development of the complex was stalled until 2000, when the Philippine Supreme Court ruled with finality the CCP's ownership of some {{convert|35|ha}} of prime real estate in the complex. The property is {{convert|62.4|ha}} of land, with the rest being occupied by the [[Government Service Insurance System]], the [[Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas]], and the Privatization and Management Office. It is part of [[Bay City, Metro Manila|Bay City]] (formerly Boulevard 2000) that spans {{convert|1500|ha}} of reclaimed land along [[Manila Bay]] which is occupied by the [[SM Prime Holdings|SM]] Central Business Park, [[Philippine National Bank]]'s Financial Center Area, and [[PAGCOR]]'s [[Entertainment City]], among others.{{cite web|url=http://www.pea.gov.ph/programs-and-projects/reclamation |title=Reclamation |publisher=Philippine Reclamation Authority |accessdate=23 May 2016}} ==Description== The complex is bounded by the Manila Bay to the north and west, the [[Philippine Navy]] headquarters to the northeast, Roxas Boulevard to the east, and [[Jose Diokno Boulevard]] to the south. It is divided into two zones: the Art Zone, and the Commercial and Entertainment Zone.{{cite web|url=http://www.pea.gov.ph/13-bay-city/24-cultural-center-of-the-philippines |title=Cultural Center of the Philippines |publisher=Philippine Reclamation Authority |accessdate=29 January 2017}} It features several [[brutalist architecture|brutalist]] structures designed in the 1960s and 1970s by [[Leandro Locsin]], such as the [[Tanghalang Pambansa]], the [[Philippine International Convention Center]], and the [[Sofitel Philippine Plaza Manila]]. Other locators in the complex include the [[Coconut Palace]], the [[Manila Film Center]] and [[Star City (amusement park)|Star City]] amusement park. ==Buildings== ===Tanghalang Pambansa=== {{Main|Tanghalang Pambansa}} [[File:Ccp ext 1.jpg|thumb|Façade of the [[Tanghalang Pambansa]]]] The [[Tanghalang Pambansa]] ({{lang-en|National Theater}}) is the flagship venue and principal offices of the [[Cultural Center of the Philippines]]. Formally called the Theater of Performing Arts, it houses three major performing arts venues, one theater for film screenings, galleries, a museum and the center's library and archives. * '''Tanghalang [[Nicanor Abelardo]] (Main Theater)''' * '''Tanghalang [[Aurelio Tolentino]] (Little Theater)''' * '''Tanghalang Huseng Batute (Studio Theater)''' Designed by National Artist for Architecture [[Leandro Locsin]], its design was based and expanded upon the unconstructed Philippine-American Friendship Center. The ''Tangahalan'' is a primary example of the architect's signature style known as the floating volume, a trait can be seen in structures indigenous to the Philippines such as the [[nipa hut]]. Being a work of a National Artist, the [[brutalist]] structure is qualified to be an important cultural landmark as stipulated in Republic Act No. 10066.Republic Act No. 10066 "Providing for the protection and conservation of the national cultural heritage, strengthening the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) and its affiliated cultural agencies, and for other purposes". Full Text available [http://www.unesconatcom.ph/docs/culture/NatlCulturalHeritage%20Act2009.pdf here] ===Tanghalang Fransisco Balagtas=== [[File:MetroManilajf9625 23.JPG|thumb|[[Tanghalang Francisco Balagtas]]]] {{main|Tanghalang Francisco Balagtas}} The [[Tanghalang Francisco Balagtas]], more commonly known by its original name of Folk Arts Theater, is a covered [[proscenium]] [[amphitheater]] is where popular concerts are usually staged. It has a seating capacity of 8,458 in ten sections. The building was originally built to seat an audience of 10,000 and was commissioned by then [[First Lady of the Philippines|First Lady]] [[Imelda Marcos]] in 1974 for the [[Miss Universe]] Pageant, which was to be held in Manila. The theater was built in record time of seventy-seven days in time for the pageant and was designed by [[Leandro V. Locsin]]. It was host to many popular musical acts of the 1980s onwards, including [[Puerto Rico|Puerto Rican]] group [[Menudo (band)|Menudo]], British pop group [[5ive]], [[Janet Jackson]], [[Gary Valenciano]] and [[Jay R Sillona|Jay R]]. The Folk Arts Theater is also used as a site by different religious groups. [[Day by Day Christian Ministries]], a large international religious organization, has leased the area since 2005. They have dedicated the Theatre as ''Bulwagan ng Panginoón'' ({{lang-en|Hall of the [[Tetragrammaton|Lord]]}}). The building is expected to be torn down in the future, subject to the development of the Complex. ===Other buildings=== [[File:MFCjf0093 35.JPG|thumb|[[Philippine International Convention Center]]]] The CCP Complex is also home to the following: * [[Philippine International Convention Center]] (Owned by the [[Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas|BSP]]) * [[Manila Film Center]] (CCP) * [[Coconut Palace]] ([[Government Service Insurance System|GSIS]]) * [[Sofitel Philippine Plaza Manila]] ([[Government Service Insurance System|GSIS]]) ==History== The Cultural Center of the Philippines was conceived in 1966 when Ferdinand Marcos issued Executive Order No. 60, establishing its board and arranging for his wife Imelda to become chair of its Board of Directors.{{cite book |last=Lico |first=Gerald |title=Edifice Complex: Power, Myth and Marcos State Architecture |year=2003 |publisher=Ateneo de Manila University Press |location=Quezon City, Philippines |isbn=978-971-550-435-5 |pages=178 p}}{{cite news |last=Ocampo |first=Ambeth |title=Sanctuary for the Filipino Soul |url=http://opinion.inquirer.net/10643/sanctuary-of-the-filipino-soul |accessdate=10 October 2011 |newspaper=Philippine Daily Inquirer |date=25 August 2011}} The Philippine-American Culture Foundation provided a Ninety Thousand Peso Grant for its construction and additional funds were taken from the Cultural Development Fund and the Special Fund for Education.{{Cite book|title=Edifice complex : power, myth, and Marcos state architecture|last=Gerard.|first=Lico|date=2003|publisher=Ateneo de Manila University Press|isbn=978-9715504355|location=Quezon City|oclc=53371189}} It soon became the premier symbol of what would be called Imelda's [[edifice complex]]. ==Expansion== A comprehensive master plan for the development of the complex was unveiled in 2003. The plan would divide the CCP Complex into six clusters, each of which will be anchored by a major building. First, the Promenade, which will tentatively be named after Lucresia Reyes-Urtula, will include retail and other mixed-use facilities, as well as dock facilities. The second cluster will be the Arts Sanctuary, which will serve as the complex's cultural core. To be anchored by the Tanghalang Pambansa, it will contain a new performing arts theater, the artists' center, a [[bandstand]], the CCP's Production Design Center, as well as other open areas. The third cluster, the Green Zone will contain a mix of museums, parks with commercial and office spaces. Fourth, the Creative Hub cluster, containing spaces for creative industries. Fifth, The Arts Living Room, envisioned to be a high-density, high-rise area that will house condominiums and similar residential projects. The final cluster, the Breezeway, will be located by low-rise, low-density commercial structures with seafront entertainment facilities. Covered walkways, plazas, and bicycle lanes are planned to connect the various buildings and clusters to ensure a pedestrian-centered design. The master plan is envisioned to be completed in four phases, from 2004 to 2014; ₱5 billion will be needed for the plan's first five years, and another ₱8 billion for the plan's latter half.[http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/storypage.aspx?StoryId=5398 ‘Commercialized’ CCP embraces the poor]. ''ABS-CBN News Online''. Retrieved 3 March 2012. A design contest was held in 2005 to design the first two clusters. Three firms won for their concepts; Syndicated Architects, Manalang-Tayag-Ilano Architects, and JPA Buensalido Design. The concepts of each winner will then be presented to prospective investors and stakeholders for approval.3 architect groups win CCP design contest. ''ABS-CBN News Online''. Retrieved 3 March 2012 Archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20060601051908/http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/storypage.aspx?StoryId=25138 here].
File:SyndicatedArch.jpg|Syndicated Architects File:JPBuensalido.jpg|JP Buensalido Designs File:Manalang.jpg|Manalang-Tayag-Ilano Architects
In 2011, Leandro V. Locsin Partners, Architects won the design contest for the Artists' Center and Performing Arts Theater, the two buildings that will anchor the Promenade and Arts Sanctuary Clusters respectively.{{cite news |title=Architectural Design Competition Exhibit Opens at CCP |url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/231474/cbb/architectural-design-competition-exhibit-opens-at-ccp |accessdate=3 March 2012 |newspaper=GMA News Online |date=5 September 2011}} The proposed Artists' Center will house offices and rehearsal spaces for the CCP's resident companies, a black box theater and rooms for educational programs.CCP Architectural Design Competition Background Information. Cultural Center of the Philippines. Retrieved 9 October 2011 Full Text available [http://culturalcenter.gov.ph/UserFiles/ccp//forms/Background%20Information%20-%20CCP%20Design%20Competition.pdf here]. The winning design is akin to a traditional [[Badjao]] village or a mangrove forest, with rooms and pavilions supported by slim pilotis. The proposed Performing Arts Theater will contain a 1,000 seat conventional proscenium theater and a black box that will seat 300-500 people. In contrast with the ''Tanghalang Pambansa's'' massive travertine block, the façade of the new theater will be dominated by its main seating bowl clad in reflective material, evoking a wave rising out of the sea. On January 19, 2016, construction of a new black box theater started with the aim of eventually integrating the new structure into the proposed Performing Arts Theater. Estimated to cost ₱50 million, the new theater will be three to four times bigger than the Tanghalang Huseng Batute, the current black box facility of the CCP.{{cite news |title=After 3 decades–and ‘against all odds’–CCP breaks ground on a new theater |url=http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/221508/after-3-decades-and-against-all-odds-ccp-breaks-ground-on-a-new-theater |accessdate=14 December 2016 |newspaper=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] |date=6 February 2016}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=note|refs= The Cultural Center of the Philippines Complex lies between [[Pasay]] and the [[City of Manila]]. The boundary between the cities is Vicente Sotto Street. Landmarks in CCP Complex that lies within the City of Manila include the Tanghalang Pambansa (National Theater), the Tanghalang Francisco Balagtas (Folks Art Theater), and the [[Coconut Palace]] which is owned by the [[Government Service Insurance System]].}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Cultural Center of the Philippines}} {{Bay City Manila}} {{Manila landmarks}} {{coord|14.553997784|N|120.975162766|E|source:frwiki_region:PH|format=dms|display=title}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Pasay]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Manila]] [[Category:Cultural centers]] [[Category:Arts districts]] [[Category:Mixed-use developments in Metro Manila]] [[Category:Landmarks in the Philippines]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Metro Manila]] [[Category:Landscapes designed by IP Santos]]
